titleStmt.title: A serious Poem on Will: Wood, Hard ware man Brazier, Tinker

publicationStmt.p: Distributed by Digital Scholarship Services at Lafayette College

lg.l: When foes are overcome, we preserve them for slaughter,
To be Hewers of wood and drawers of water,
Now although to draw water is not very Good,
Yet we all should rejoice to be Hewers of Wood,
I own it hath often provok'd me to mutter,
That a rogue so obscure should make such a Clutter.
But antient Philosophers wisely remark,
That old rotten wood will shine in the dark.
The Heathens we read had Gods made of Wood,
Which could do them no harm, if they did them no good,
But this idol Wood may do us much evil,
Their Gods were of Wood, but our wood is ye Devil.
To cut down fine Wood is a very bad thing,
And Yet we al know how much it will bring.
Then if Cutting down wood brings money Good store,
Our Money to keep Let us cut down one more;
Now hear an old tale there antiently Stood
I forget in what church an Image ofWood.
Concerning this Image there went a prediction,
It could burn a whole forest, nor was it a fiction,
'Twas Cut into faggots & put in to ye flame,
To burn an old fryar, one Fforest by name,
My tale is a wise one if well understood,
Find you but ye Fryar, and I'le find yeWood.
Some say among Scholars there is a great doubt
From what kind of Wood this tree is cut out,
Teague made a good pun with a brogue in his Speech,
And said by my Shoul he's a son of a beech.
Some call him, a thorn ye Curse of ye Nation,
As Thorns were designe'd to be from ye Creation.
Some think 'twas cut out of Poisonous Yew,
Beneath twhose Ill shades a Plant Never Grew.
Some Say it was'twas a burch, although very odd,
For none but a dunce wou'd come under his rod.
But I'll tell you ye Secret, & pray do not blab,
He is an old Stump cut out of a Crab.
And England hath put this Crab to a hard use
To Cudgell our bones & for drink give us verjuice.
And therefore this witness now justly may Boast,
That none are more properly knights of ye Post.
I Ne'er Cou'd Endure my Talent to smother.
I have told you one tale I'll tell you another.
A Ioyner to fasten a Saint to a Nich,
Made a large Auger·hole in ye Images breech.
But finding yea Statue to make no Complaint,
He'd ne'er be Convinced it was a true Saint.
When ye true Wood arrives as he will there's no doubt,
For thats but a sham Wood they carry about.
What stuff he is made on you quickly shall find,
If you make ye same trial & Bore him behind.
I'll hold you a groat when you wimble his bum,
He'll bellow as loud as ye Devil in a drum;
From me I declare, you shall have no denial,
There can be no harm in making a trial
And when to ye Ioy of my Heart he hath roar'd
You may show him about for a New growing board.
Hear one story more and then I will Stop,
I dreamt Wood was told he should dye by a drop.
So my·thought he resolv'd no liquor to taste,
For fear ye first drop might as well be his last.
But dreams are like Oracles its hard to explain them,
It prov'd that he dyed of a drop at 1Ye Place of excution at Dublin. Kilmainham.
I weak'd with delight, & not without hope,
Very soon to see Wood drop down from a rope;
How we and how he at each other should grin,
Its kindness to hold a Friend up by ye chin.
But hold says ye herald I cannot agree,
For Metal upon Metal is false Heraldry.
Why that may be true, but Wood upon Wood,
I'll maintain by my life is Heraldry Good.334-172Y
